#Text=Alice Headwards-Hunter
#Text=Alice Mabel Headwards-Hunter , LAH , FRCSEd ( late 1800s – 11 September 1973 ) was the first woman to become a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh .
#Text=While she was the first woman to be given a seat in the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh , she declined the seat and instead went to pursue work abroad [ 1 ] .
#Text=While she chose to decline this seat she has pioneered the way for many future female physicians to come .
#Text=She spent her professional life in India , caring mainly for women and children .
#Text=The Indian Government recognised her service by the award of the Kaiser-i-Hind medal . [ 2 ]
#Text=Early life
#Text=Headwards-Hunter was born in India in the late 1800s , the daughter of an Indian Army Officer .
#Text=She received her education in England and in 1910 graduated LAH as a licentiate of the Apothecaries Hall of Ireland . [ 3 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=Headwards-Hunter returned to India in 1918 and worked initially in a British troop hospital as a Captain in the Royal Army Medical Corps . [ 2 ]
#Text=After the war she took a post at the Peshawar Municipal Hospital focusing on women and child health .
#Text=She returned to Europe and in 1920 , became the first woman to obtain the F.R.C.S.Ed diploma from the Royal College of Surgeons Edinburgh . [ 4 ]
#Text=In 1919 , the Sex Disqualification Removal Act was passed in Great Britain making it illegal to exclude any woman from employment because of her gender .

#Text=In the months following the passing of this Act , Nancy Astor became the first woman to sit as Member of Parliament and , on 20 October 1920 , Headwards-Hunter became the first woman to be admitted as a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh . [ 5 ]
#Text=Returning to Calcutta in 1923 , she set up a private practice concerned with woman and children . [ 2 ]
#Text=Hunter was actively involved in development of health visitor training in India . [ 2 ]
#Text=She was also Divisional Surgeon to the Calcutta Brigade of the St John Ambulance , an organisation that she was to support throughout her life .
#Text=She particularly valued the honour of Serving Sister and honorary life member of St John Ambulance awarded in 1946 . [ 6 ]
#Text=She became President of the YMCA in Calcutta and later President of all India YWCA . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1933 , she went as a front line St John ’s Ambulance doctor to the area which had been devastated by the Monghyr earthquake .
#Text=The Second World War saw her practice intensify particularly when fighting reached the Indian/Burmese border . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1942 , she was one of the first women to go into Nepal , which at that time , remained a closed country .
#Text=She was to attend the Crown Princess of Nepal .
#Text=The following year , during the Bengal famine , she was asked by the Bengal government to set up a temporary hospital for child famine victims . [ 2 ]
#Text=Her work was recognised in 1945 when she was awarded the Kaisar-i-Hind Silver Medal . [ 2 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=She continued to work in India and Pakistan until her retirement in the 1950s when she and her husband moved to Ireland .
#Text=Death
#Text=She died in Bruntsfield Hospital , Edinburgh on 11 September 1973 . [ 2 ]
#Text=Legacy
#Text=In 2007 , the Royal College of Surgeons Edinburgh awarded the first Hunter-Doig Medal .
#Text=The medal is presented to a female RCSEd Member or Fellow in recognition of excellence . [ 4 ]
#Text=It is named for Alice Headwards-Hunter as first female Fellow of the College and Caroline Doig , the first female member of the College Council .
#Text=The award is presented to female surgeons who show both excellence and potential to advance their field .
#Text=The Surgeons Hall Museum wrote that this award is given because , " [ ... ] two female surgeons both of whom have achieved something no women had before .
